results.title: Managing stress. Part III: What you bring on yourself
results.brief_description: Explains “Type A” personalities who drive themselves beyond normal limits distinguishing between the stress response and other emotional states such as anger and frustration. Presents suggestions for lessening stress by exercise, walking away from unresolvable situations, seeking professional help or joining support groups.

results.title: Managing stress. Part II: What the world dishes out
results.brief_description: Details stresses that can evoke health threatening responses including loss of self esteem, boredom, role conflicts, excessive responsibility, lack of control and work overload. Demonstrates deep breathing and meditation techniques for temporarily relieving stress and prevention through cognitive restructuring.

results.title: Managing stress in the workplace
results.brief_description: Stress is the body’s reaction to stimuli to enable us to meet life’s daily challenges, but the dilemma is achieving just the right level of stress to deliver an optimum performance. This video helps you detect signs of stress in your workplace and take practical steps to reduce stress and improve health, safety and effectiveness at work.

results.title: Managing stress
results.brief_description: Addresses stress from a management perspective outlining recognition of undue stress and stress management strategies. Emphasises that manageable stress levels can result in high productivity while excessive, improperly managed stress levels can be debilitating. Contains B&W sequences.

results.title: Managing soil structure
results.brief_description: This video looks at the current soil structure of many of the intensive farming areas of Victoria and how good soil structure is the key to profitable and sustainable agriculture. It investigates current farming practices and reaffirms that it is necessary to assess current farming practices and the way in which we treat our valuable ancient and fragile soils. Some of the problems described are; Crusting, soil fragility, impermeability to water, slaking, soil compaction, wind erosion and waterlogging. The suggested solutions to these problems include minimum tillage techniques - stubble retention, deep ripping and direct drilling. This video tells how farmers recognised soil problems on their farms and how they altered their management systems in order to improve soil structure and farm profitability.

results.title: Managing orchard mites
results.creator_credit: Roger Seccombe, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description: Spraying orchards for pests and diseases which attack crops often destroys the balance between insect pests and their natural predators. This was the case with spider mites. Research into this problem has led to successful control by combining a modified spray program compatible with introduced mite predators.
results.description: Spraying orchards for pests and diseases which attack crops often destroys the balance between insect pests and their natural predators. This was the case with spider mites. results.title: Managing meetings (Captioned)
results.brief_description: This training video assists in the managing of business meetings. Before a meeting it is important to establish who will be at the meeting, why and what the meeting is for. Although staff often bemoan meetings, they don’t have to be a waste of time, by following these guidelines: be convinced that the meeting is necessary; know the objectives of the meeting; start on time and finish on time; stick to the time allocation for each topic; resolve any conflicts that arise; make sure the intended outcomes are achieved; list the actions that each individual must undertake, post-meeting.

results.title: Managing discrimination in the workplace
results.brief_description: This video informs participants about the managerial aspects of discrimination in the workplace and how they can contribute to the promotion and creation of a discrimination free work environment. Explains the difference between Indirect and Direction Discrimination, develops skills to recognise different forms of discrimination, points out the consequences that can result if a business allows or permits discrimination and presents five key steps to promoting a discrimination free workplace. A manual which complements the video may be borrowed as a separate loan item.

results.title: Managing currencies (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Global Economy”.
The value of currency exchange rates has a crucial role in a nation’s economy, affecting the rate of import and export, as well as the rate of unemployment and inflation. In this episode of the Open Learning Economics course we study the ways in which governments can intervene in fixing a value to their currency. The first part of the episode we look at the economic crisis precipitated by a strong US dollar in the 1980s. President Ronald Reagan’s committment to laissez-faire economics meant that the German Deutschmark and the Japanese Yen consistently traded more effectively against the US dollar, resulting in loss of production and increasing unemployment in the United States. A panel of economists analyse the effectiveness of the Plaza Accord, initiated by Ronald Reagan and James Baker in the late 1980s, to reverse some of the imbalances of a free-floating exchange rate. In the second example, we look at the attempt of the Thatcher government in Great Britain to fix the exchange rate of the pound, in an attempt to curtail spiralling inflation and unemployment.

results.title: Managing creatively
results.creator_credit: Ron Tanner, David Evans and Millbank Films
results.brief_description: Tells the story of a manager whose creativity is stifled at work. Shows how he crosses the barriers which block his creativity and how he finds he can release his own ideas and the ideas of others for productive work.
